title: Brainstem Compression via Tortuous Vertebral Artery
chief_complaint: I've had headaches and dizziness for 30 years, but about a year and a half ago I started getting spinning vertigo, ringing in my left ear, and a feeling of fullness.

problem_summary.onset: Chronic symptoms began 30 years ago; acute exacerbation with vertigo 1.5 years prior to evaluation.
problem_summary.course: Chronic symptoms waxed and waned; recent vertigo episodes occurred weekly for several weeks before subsiding.
problem_summary.laterality: Left ear specific symptoms (tinnitus, fullness); bilateral hearing loss.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Frontal and temporo-parietal headaches, imbalance, whirling vertigo, left ear fullness, tinnitus.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Headaches increased in intensity; instability continued.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking explanation after numerous failed medical interventions and a diagnosis of Meniere's disease.

history.present_illness: Patient reports a 30-year history of headaches and imbalance. 1.5 years ago, developed whirling vertigo, left ear fullness, and tinnitus. Episodes were weekly. Previously diagnosed with Meniere's disease.
history.otologic_history: Recent diagnosis of Meniere's disease due to episodic vertigo and fullness.
history.medical_psych_history: Numerous medical interventions over 30 years with little relief.
history.prior_management: Medical consultation sought for many years.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild to moderate high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, bilaterally symmetrical.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent speech recognition bilaterally, though slightly poorer on the left.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Contralateral reflexes present but elevated for left ear stimulation compared to right. Absent at 4000 Hz for left stimulation.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR). Right ear normal. Left ear abnormal: only Wave V present with extended latency. Abnormal Interaural Latency Difference (ILD). Wave V lost at high repetition rate (80 dB nHL) in left ear.

tests.name: Dichotic Digit Test
tests.key_findings: Dichotic Digit Test. Performance revealed much poorer performance for the left ear.

tests.name: Radiologic Findings (Arteriogram/MRI)
tests.key_findings: Radiologic Findings (Arteriogram and MRI). Large, tortuous vertebral vessel on the left side. MRI indicated the artery displaced the brainstem to the right.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with symmetrical mild-to-moderate high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. However, retrocochlear testing reveals significant left-sided abnormalities. Acoustic reflexes are elevated/absent with left ear stimulation. ABR is grossly abnormal on the left (poor morphology, missing early waves, rate sensitivity) with an abnormal ILD. Dichotic listening is significantly degraded in the left ear. These findings, combined with the arteriogram showing a large tortuous vertebral artery displacing the brainstem, suggest left brainstem involvement (vascular loop compression) affecting the auditory pathway.
counseling_points: Explain that while the hearing loss looks even on the graph, the 'stress tests' (ABR, reflexes, dichotic digits) show the left nerve/brainstem pathway is struggling.
Discuss the correlation between the dizziness/headaches and the vascular finding (vertebral artery loop) seen on imaging.
Clarify that the symptoms previously diagnosed as Meniere's are likely related to the vascular compression of the brainstem/nerve.
Refer to neurology/neurosurgery for management of the vascular compression.
notes_for_actor: You have been dealing with these vague symptoms for 30 years and are likely frustrated by the lack of answers.
The recent vertigo was very scary and intense compared to your chronic dizziness.
You might be skeptical of new tests since previous medical interventions didn't help.
Emphasize the headachesâ€”they are frontal and on the side of your head.
